Title: Jeff and Renate’s eHaus – 12 years of comfort and savings
Content:
As part of our 15th birthday celebrations, we visited three of our original clients to see firsthand the impact their homes have had on their lives and check how the homes are performing after all this time. Here is the second client story in our birthday series, make sure you check out the other stories too.

Jeff and Renate also moved into their eHaus Euro in 2013. Both from the UK and now retired, Renate was a nurse and Jeff owned retail shops in the UK, following a stint in the army as a radio technician. To date, their home in Whanganui has saved an impressive 42,480kg of carbon thanks to the predicted heat energy savings of 95%!  

Having lived in the UK and built two houses before, the couple felt they should be able to improve on their past homes. When they heard about eHaus building high performing homes, they began their own research which “proved very decisively that this was the right way to build,” says Jeff. “Our UK house performance was good but did require central heating and a log fire. Our first NZ build was reasonable but as soon as the sun went down the heat disappeared through the walls and poor-quality windows, even though they were double glazed!”

Now in their eHaus, with the interior design done by Renate and carpentry, electrical and plumbing work completed by Jeff, Jeff says the home is “exactly what we wanted and more. Having a ventilation system and fresh air all the time is my favourite aspect.”

“I have been in houses in New Zealand where it’s quite uncomfortable in most of the rooms. Windows are dripping with condensation. The cost of keeping this type of home must be crippling.” But that is not the case for Jeff and Renate who live in comfort every day. The 5KW photovoltaic solar panels and solar thermal hot water systems means the home generates its own energy, providing huge savings, and in the middle of a New Zealand winter, had a power bill of $138 (July 2024) and in January 2025 it was only $23 (and that includes charging the Electric Vehicle!).

“If the New Zealand building code ever comes up to the eHaus standard, just think how much healthier, richer and warmer our people would be. If you’re thinking of building a new home, then building a standard house is the worst decision you could ever make. Build a high performing home!”

Jeff Williams

Your can find out more about this home here.

Title: Verena and Rudolf’s eHaus still exceeding performance standards after 13 years
Content:
As part of our 15th birthday celebrations, we visited three of our original clients to see firsthand the impact their homes have had on their lives and check how the homes are performing after all this time. Here is the last story in our birthday series, make sure you check out the other stories too.

Verena and Rudolf live in the first eHaus in Taranaki which they designed and built in 2012. Growing up in Switzerland Rudolf lived in a house from 1760, and Verena’s was built in 1603, however it was common to have an energy efficient home there.

Arriving from Switzerland 52 years ago on their OE, they fell in love with New Zealand and decided to stay. For most of their working lives, they were also farmers in Stratford then Oakura, living in farmhouses built to the minimum building code. One of their homes was so inefficient and lacked weather tightness that “when we water blasted the cladding, the water would seep inside of the house” says Verena.

During a trip home in the 1990’s they attended an open day at a low-energy house in the village where Verena grew up. Building an energy-efficient and high-performing felt right to the couple, but it wasn’t until 2011 that they started researching someone to build a new home for them – perfect timing as the eHaus website had just launched.

Their eHaus Euro provides a comfy home for the couple and when asked what their favourite aspect of living in an eHaus is, Verena says “It feels comfortable. It’s not moist and there’s no condensation. I can hang up my towel at night and its dry in the morning.”

When the home was designed, the eHaus energy modelling showed their home would have 94% predicted heat energy savings and as at 10 March 2025, has saved a whopping 57,276kg of carbon. When the build was complete, the final airtightness test gave a result of 0.38 air changes per hour, well below the maximum 0.6 AC n50 required for Passive House certification.

When asked about their power bills and the performance of their home, Verena says “the performance has never changed.” Their monthly power bills range between $220-$250 but Verena is quick to point out that they are charging an electric car, pump their own water, and have a large workshop with machinery which all uses more power than a typical home.

The recent airtightness test result was 0.51 AC n50. Verena was right, while there was a slight change from the 2012 result, their home is still performing within the requirements of a Passive House all these years later.
Image Alt Text: Kulls
_yoast_wpseo_title: eHaus still exceeding performance standards after 13 years

Title: The Post article: Waikato budget expert withdraws KiwiSaver early to buy eHaus - no regrets
Content:
Clare and Peter decided to buy a high-performing, energy-efficient eHaus that maintains a 20 degree temperature year round after Clare’s Rheumatologist advised that their “old and cold”, 1940s bungalow was making her rheumatoid arthritis worse.

She was becoming miserable in the old house, even though they had insulated the ceiling and underfloor and put in double glazing.

Clare says the new high-performing eHaus has taken away stresses. “I don’t have to be covered up with three or four layers” she says. “I could have held off and been really, really unwell. But we decided to make life a bit more enjoyable.”

👉 Read Clare and Peter’s full story here or watch their video below.

Title: Foundations complete and ready to rise
Content:
Getting Lydia Pl out of the ground has been a carefully coordinated process, with each stage requiring close collaboration between our team, engineers, and Council.

We kicked off with the foundation footings for the garage and landscaping retaining walls, followed by the blockwork for both the garage and one of the retaining walls. From there, we moved into tanking and protecting the exterior garage walls before installing drainage and completing the backfilling – a critical step for site stability and safety.

With the backfilling complete, we were able to move onto piling. Using an auger, the team drilled pile holes for both the house and decks. Despite challenging weather conditions, they pushed through to prepare the piles and garage slab for concrete. A major milestone was achieved when we poured the concrete for both the piles and the garage slab on the same day. The piles were completed using a line pump and tremie method to displace the water and ensure a solid pour.

We’re proud of the progress so far and excited for what’s next – constructing the sub-floor and watching Lydia Pl begin to take shape above ground.

Stay tuned for more updates as this beautiful build continues.

Title: MBIE announce there will be no roll back of insulation standards
Content:
At eHaus, we welcome the decision not to roll back higher insulation standards and to acknowledge the role insulation plays in improving the health, comfort, and energy performance of New Zealand homes. We commend the Minister for listening to the industry.

We agree that increased insulation alone does not cause overheating. However, our experience delivering high-performance homes has shown that simply adding more insulation without considering essential design factors such as orientation, glazing, shading and ventilation, can contribute to overheating and owner discomfort.

Insulation is a critical part of the solution, but it must be integrated into a holistic design approach. High-performance homes are the result of careful planning and attention to detail at every stage, not insulation in isolation.

Regarding affordability, while higher insulation levels can increase upfront construction costs, there is extensive evidence both internationally and in New Zealand demonstrating that the long-term benefits (including reduced energy use, improved health outcomes, increasing work productivity) more than justify the initial investment. It is important that policymakers and industry leaders continue to communicate clear, evidence-based information about these benefits to homeowners and builders alike.

eHaus remains committed to delivering homes that are warm in winter, cool in summer, and healthy all year round. Through high performance design principles and rigorous construction standards, we can achieve buildings that perform exceptionally well without compromising comfort or sustained affordability.


Read the full RNZ article here.
_yoast_wpseo_metadesc: We welcome the decision not to roll back higher insulation standards & to acknowledge the role insulation plays in improving the NZ homes.
_yoast_wpseo_title: High insulation standards to remain | eHaus

Title: Floor prep and sweeping views
Content:
At Lydia Place, the flooring stage has been all about precision and performance.

To support the James Hardie Secura flooring, our floor joists were spaced closer than standard. This dense fibre cement product was selected for its acoustic properties, essential given the home’s location close to a flight path and it also contributes to airtightness, a key factor in high performance homes.

Once the flooring was laid, we landed the wall frames and brought in Scafit to stand the scaffolding. This gave our team a safe and stable platform to proceed with standing the frames and begin shaping the gable forms and glazed dining link that define the home’s Japandi-inspired architecture.

With the flooring laid, we reached a moment where the design began to come to life. Standing on the completed floor, we now fully appreciate the end views, sweeping across native bush and out toward the Tararua Ranges. It’s a powerful reminder of why this site was chosen and how the home’s layout is designed to frame and celebrate those vistas.

This stage is a turning point where the structure begins to reflect the vision.

Title: Waikato Times article: How a high performance home changes life
Content:
Craig and Melissa Lawrence used to live in a house so cold, damp and draughty that they’d find slugs on the hallway floor.

“We wanted a home that’s a constant and comfortable temperature year-round, with low moisture levels and minimal energy usage to achieve it. The idea that you can come home from work or school on a miserable winter’s day - or hot summer’s day - and walk into a house at a comfortable temperature, was a huge drawcard.”

The result is a new high performance eHaus, that’s the same comfortable 18 to 19 degree temperature every morning, without heating on, even when it’s -1 degree in Cambridge, as it has been this month.

Built by eHaus Waikato, and designed by The Architecture People, the home is designed to maximise natural light, airflow, and thermal efficiency.

👉 Read the full story here.

Title: Frames up!
Content:
The build at Lydia Place is rising fast and during May we hit a major milestone: wall and roof framing was underway!

This isn’t your standard framing job. At Lydia, we’re building smarter from the inside out. One of the key differences? Our external walls are 140mm thick, compared to the typical 90mm you’d find in most New Zealand homes. That extra 50mm might not sound like much, but it makes a big difference, allowing us to pack in 50% more insulation.

We’ve also installed the dwangs on their edge, rather than flat, which allows for a continuous layer of insulation between the studs. This small and clever detail helps eliminate thermal bridging and supports the airtightness and energy efficiency we’re aiming for.

Why does that matter? More insulation and better detailing mean improved thermal performance — essential for achieving the eHaus Pacific criteria we’re targeting. It helps keep the home warm in winter, cool in summer, and energy-efficient all year round, all while creating a healthier, more comfortable living environment.

This stage of the build is where the structure really starts to take shape, highlighted by those four striking gable ends. You can now walk through the spaces, see the layout come to life, and get a feel for how the home will function. It’s always an exciting moment for the team and a great time to appreciate the craftsmanship and precision that goes into every detail.

Title: Roof installation
Content:
The Lydia build continues to take shape, and June marked another major milestone - roof installation. As with every stage of this high-performance home, the materials and methods we’ve chosen are intentional, durable, and designed to support high performance principles.

We’ve selected Colorsteel Maxam in a standard corrugate profile, finished in the timeless shade of Titania. This choice offers more than just good looks. Colorsteel Maxam is the next generation of Colorsteel, designed to withstand New Zealand’s diverse climate conditions, making it ideal for the Lydia build’s exposed site. The corrugate profile adds a familiar architectural rhythm, while Titania’s soft, neutral tone complements the overall palette of the home.

Choosing a light-coloured roof like Titania isn’t just an aesthetic decision, it’s a performance one. Light roofs reflect sunlight rather than absorbing it, helping to reduce overheating in summer and maintain a more stable indoor temperature. In effect, it acts like a polar ice cap, bouncing solar radiation away from the home and supporting both energy efficiency and sustainability. This passive cooling strategy reduces the need for mechanical cooling and contributes to the home's overall thermal comfort.

Beneath the steel lies a key component of our airtightness and weather protection strategy: Siga Majcoat. This premium roof underlay is a standout performer in the world of building membranes. It’s highly breathable, UV-resistant, and robust enough to support the airtightness and moisture control required for Passive House certification. By choosing Majcoat, we’re investing in long-term durability and indoor comfort.

The roof isn’t just a lid, it’s a critical layer in the home’s thermal envelope. Every product we’ve chosen contributes to the Lydia build’s goal of energy efficiency, durability, and occupant wellbeing. From the visible Colorsteel cladding to the hidden layers of Siga Majcoat, this roof is built to perform.
